content.value: A derivative represents the rate of change of a function with respect to a variable
The derivative is the slope of the tangent line to a curve at a given point

content.definition: The instantaneous rate of change of a function at a point

content.value: f'(x) = lim(h→0) [f(x+h) - f(x)] / h
There are several fundamental rules for computing derivatives
Power Rule: d/dx(x^n) = nx^(n-1)
Constant Rule: d/dx(c) = 0
Sum Rule: d/dx[f(x) + g(x)] = f'(x) + g'(x)
Find the derivative of f(x) = x³: Using power rule, f'(x) = 3x²
Memorizing common derivatives helps solve problems quickly

content.definition: Derivatives of sine, cosine, tangent and other trigonometric functions

content.value: The chain rule is used to find derivatives of composite functions
Find derivative of sin(x²): d/dx[sin(x²)] = cos(x²) × 2x = 2x·cos(x²)

content.definition: A function formed by combining two or more functions, where the output of one function becomes the input of another

content.value: When differentiating a product of two functions, use the product rule
d/dx[f(x)·g(x)] = f'(x)·g(x) + f(x)·g'(x)
Derivative of x·sin(x): (1)·sin(x) + x·cos(x) = sin(x) + x·cos(x)
The quotient rule is used for derivatives of quotients
Derivative of x/sin(x): [sin(x) - x·cos(x)] / sin²(x)
We can take derivatives of derivatives to get higher order derivatives
The second derivative represents the rate of change of the rate of change
f''(x) = d²f/dx² = d/dx[f'(x)]
